channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [GROOVY-6491] Conflicting module versions in OSGi context
item.description:
We use equinox as runtime platform to drive our applciation. Given two bundles A and B where each of them uses a dedicated Groovy Version (e.g. A imports 2.1.1 and B imports 2.1.8) we got an unexpected Exception:

 groovy.lang.GroovyRuntimeException: Conflicting module versions. Module [groovy-all is loaded in version 2.2.1 and you are trying to load version 2.1.1
	at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.metaclass.MetaClassRegistryImpl$DefaultModuleListener.onModule(MetaClassRegistryImpl.java:509)
	at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.m12n.ExtensionModuleScanner.scanExtensionModuleFromProperties(ExtensionModuleScanner.java:78)
	at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.m12n.ExtensionModuleScanner.scanExtensionModuleFromMetaInf(ExtensionModuleScanner.java:72)
	at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.m12n.ExtensionModuleScanner.scanClasspathModules(ExtensionModuleScanner.java:54)
	at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.metaclass.MetaClassRegistryImpl.<init>(MetaClassRegistryImpl.java:110)
	at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.metaclass.MetaClassRegistryImpl.<init>(MetaClassRegistryImpl.java:71)
	at groovy.lang.GroovySystem.<clinit>(GroovySystem.java:33)

The problem seems to be caused by org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.m12n.ExtensionModuleScanner introdcued with Groovy 2.1.2 as fix for GROOVY-6008, that scans all resources to find all MODULE_META_INF_FILE META-INF/services/org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.ExtensionModule that are accessible via classLoader.getResources, in our case the bundle class loader. Although the classes of the second groovy jar are not exposed to the bundle class loader it may of course see the JAR file and it's META-INF entries.

From the bundles class laoder perspective it would make sense (is even necessary ) to skip a JAR whose classes it can't see. Maybe this issue can be fixed by changing the org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.metaclass.MetaClassRegistryImpl.DefaultModuleListener#onModule(ExtensionModule module) method.

If the loadedModule.getVersion() does not match with module.getVersion() it should be checked whether a surrogate class of the module can be loaded. If the surrogate class can't be loaded the module should be silently skipped rather throwing a runtime exception.
item.summary: Conflicting module versions in OSGi context

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: What I don't understand is why the resource is even visible. I would have assumed OSGI can hide it and would do so by default.

OSGi provides a mean to import and export classes on a package level. The im- and export are driven by means of the Jars META-INF/MANIFEST.MF files, that include the package meta information, e.g. version or resolution.

E.g. a bundle may specifiy in its Manifest file it optionally requires package org.codehaus.groovy with version 2.1.1. Thus the MANIFEST includes a statement such as

Import-Package: <...>,
 org.codehaus.groovy;resolution:=optional;version="2.1.1",
 <...>

Now if at runtime the bundle request a class of the org.codehaus.groovy package the bundles class loader scans the entire classpath for resources that export the desired package. For that reason the Jars/resources have to be visible.

@blackdrag: Finally I found out why the resource is even visible.

I would have assumed too, that OSGI can hide it and would do so by default. And yes, OSGi would do that but Eclipse-Equinox may break that assumption.

The problem is caused by the Groovy Jar's MANIFEST declaration

Eclipse-BuddyPolicy: dependent

Given this tag the bunlde class loader of the Groovy Jars considers more than just the locally visible resources and applies buddy class loading (i.e. refer to org.eclipse.osgi.internal.loader.BundleLoader#findClassInternal and org.eclipse.osgi.internal.loader.buddy.PolicyHandler#doBuddyClassLoading).

A possible fix for our problem would be to remove the Eclipse-BuddyPolicy from the groovy-all Manifest. If I do that, everythning works well in our application.

An other possible workaround might be to solely issue a warning message rather than throwing an exception if a conflicting Groovy module version is encountered. I'm convinced that in practice that the real conflict would be rarely encountered. Maybe it would be an beeter idea to use java sealing to prevent use of mixed jars (see docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/deployment/jar/sealman.html).

Removing "Eclipse-BuddyPolicy: dependent" from groovy manifest is probably a good idea, as it is equinox-specific and is not working using groovy jar in other osgi implementation like felix.
Also Eclipse-BuddyPolicy: dependent can introduce performances issue (see https://wiki.eclipse.org/Context_Class_Loader_Enhancements)

my guess is 'DynamicImport-Package: *' is probably enough

Found this via http://markmail.org/message/gngevc3tqszdnipm#query:+page:1+mid:nnm6lzlgsky5llx4+state:results

Would it be possible to target this issue for 2.4.11 or 2.5.0? When profiling an application using Oracle Flight Recorder. I am seeing hundreds of exceptions being thrown because the *Customizer and *BeanInfo classes that do not exist are trying to be loaded.

java.lang.Throwable.<init>(String, Throwable)
java.lang.Exception.<init>(String, Throwable)

java.lang.ClassNotFoundException.<init>(String)
java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(String)
java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(String, boolean)
sun.misc.Launcher$AppClassLoader.loadClass(String, boolean)
java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(String)
java.lang.Class.forName0(String, boolean, ClassLoader, Class)
java.lang.Class.forName(String, boolean, ClassLoader)
com.sun.beans.finder.ClassFinder.findClass(String)
com.sun.beans.finder.ClassFinder.findClass(String, ClassLoader)
java.beans.Introspector.findCustomizerClass(Class)
java.beans.Introspector.getTargetBeanDescriptor()
java.beans.Introspector.getBeanInfo()
java.beans.Introspector.getBeanInfo(Class)
groovy.lang.MetaClassImpl$15.run()
java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(PrivilegedExceptionAction)
groovy.lang.MetaClassImpl.addProperties()
groovy.lang.MetaClassImpl.initialize()
org.codehaus.groovy.reflection.ClassInfo.getMetaClassUnderLock()
org.codehaus.groovy.reflection.ClassInfo.getMetaClass()
org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.metaclass.MetaClassRegistryImpl.getMetaClass(Class)
org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.InvokerHelper.getMetaClass(Class)

eric-milles opened a new pull request, #2298:
URL: https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/2298

`MetaInfExtensionModule` catches and logs `ClassNotFoundException`, `InaccessibleObjectException` and `LinkageError` when loading declared extension classes. This should result in a module that has no classes to produce methods. Since this condition is logged already, do not pass an empty module along to the `ExtensionModuleListener` where the duplicate version check is done.
